text:
Problem Overview

Students model addition and subtraction on chip-board displays. Students explore relationships between addition and subtraction as well. One chip color indicates positive values, and the other chip color indicates negative values.

This Problem promotes informal experiences with addition and subtraction of signed numbers. Investigation 2 will formalize algorithms for completing these operations. Note that this model is a representation of integer arithmetic, while the directed distance (number line) model from Problems 1.1 and 1.2 is a continuous model that can represent fraction and decimal numbers and lengths. This chip model lends itself to the take-away interpretation of subtraction.

Teacher Note: In Investigation 2, students will develop algorithms for addition and subtraction of integers. To prepare for this collect number sentences that they use in Investigation 1 in digital Learning Logs or on posters like these:

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Informally develop methods for adding and subtracting integers using real world context and chip boards.

Notice

  • The sum of two opposite numbers is zero (Additive Inverse Property)
  • A connection between addition and subtraction with integers.

NWDYK

How can you use a chip board to represent addition and subtraction of integers?

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

Discuss the context of describing finances as “in the black” or “in the red.” Check to see if your students have ever heard these terms used and in what context.

Students may be able to share stories of saving money in order to make a purchase. Or they may recall borrowing against future income (e.g., their allowance or money from a babysitting job) in order to buy a gift. They should be able to identify situations in which they have been “in the black” and “in the red."

Implementation Note: This problem may take 2 days for students to fully explore the ideas and to discuss their findings as a whole class. Giving them this time to investigate creating zeroes will be beneficial when they use it to create algorithms in Investigation 2. (Time)

Presenting the Challenge

Introduce chipboards and how to use them. Have students represent 5 with 5 black chips. Repeat with -5 and 5 red chips. Go back to +5 and ask if there is any way to represent +5 with red and black chips? (This gets the idea of zeros created with a red and black chip out for discussion. An example would be 6 black chips and 1 red chip.) Repeat with 0, +12, - 7, - 25 as needed. Students don’t have to master this idea yet. They will continue to work with “zeros” in this problem.

Discuss the situation in the introduction of the student edition about Amber’s Game of Zero. Display Amber’s chipboard that is in the Student Edition. Give partners a set of two-color chips. Launch students into the Problem to investigate chipboard situations. Have students work in groups of 2. Have 2 color chips and chip boards available for students to use as they are working on the problem.

What If Situation D is playing The Game of Zero. Ideally you would want students to play this in teams or if you are short on time you can play this as a whole class. If you are playing this in teams, Distribute Learning Aid 1.3A: Cards and Learning Aid 1.3B: Recording Sheet. Use the digital drawing tool with chip stamps, or have 2 color chips, chip boards, and a number cube available for students to use.

Make sure that students understand the rules of the game.

Suggested Questions

  • Suppose each team has the following board (image below). The first team rolls a two. What moves can be made? (The team has the option of adding 2 black chips, adding 2 red chips, subtracting 2 black chips, or subtracting 2 red chips. The team could also choose to remove two black and two red which is zero.)
  • When does the game end? (Play continues until the board has a value of zero.)
Have students play the game one time all the way through. Have them play it a second time but this time they record a number sentence to represent each move.
